comments.commentBody: I agree they should have gotten outside opinions, but not from China.  Everything I have read about Chinese construction, would have made the mistakes seen here minor.  They have poured more concrete in the past fifteen years than the United States has in the past century, BUT it is such a low grade (wrong aggregates, too much water, and not enough cement) that it won't hold up as required.  Their steel isn't of a good quality either.  I do industrial/commercial concrete design for a living, having started out as a carpenter/finisher.  Now thirty plus years and a college degree, I can truthfully say I know concrete.  I take pride in what I do, but I am afraid this is not a project that is going to end well.  A billion dollars?  That is a lot of Portland Cement, rebar and experienced workers to make sure it all comes together for a good finished project.  This sounds more like something Jimmy Hoffa would have had a hand in.

Surely you jest? re: "the relative lack of input from the other world powers;" Independence and self-sufficiency is what the project was about. That is why they [Panama] took ownership of the existing canal - built by US.

The economic stimulus is based on free market rather than [foreign] government "assistance/buy-in." Business 101 is quite simple: address a need; figure out cost to build [to meet that need]; account for O&M; and set a price. If it makes financial sense then execute the project; conversely if it doesn't don't waste the time or money - unless of course once can delude oneself into thinking they can cut costs sufficiently tomake it pencil out [all too often the case, e.g. $3.4B in claims pending resolution.

I think if you read and think about the point made in the first two sentences of the article you may understand why the Obama administration was not pro-active with the government of Panama in planning and building this expansion.

“On July 8, 2009, the champagne finally flowed.

After an intense two-year competition, a consortium led by a Spanish company in severe financial distress learned that its rock-bottom bid of $3.1 billion had won the worldwide competition to build a new set of locks for the historic Panama Canal.”

The contract was negotiated primarily during the Bush Administration which ended on January 20, 2009 with the first inauguration of Barack Obama as the 44th President of the United States. Obama was in office only the final 5 months of the contract negotiations and project planning. You may remember that during those five months, the Obama Administration had its hands full trying to straighten out the world-wide economic catastrophe created by his predecessor.

Fantastic article and exposé. What struck me the most about this project is the relative lack of input from the other world powers. It's hard to overstate the strategic value of the Panama canal. One would think that countries like the US and China would have intervened once rumors about shoddy construction and questionable design choices began to surface.

Furthermore, at $3 billion, this project is relatively cheap compared to other mega-construction projects. For comparison, Seattle is currently considering a $50 billion expansion of its light rail system. So, even with small assistance/buy-in from other countries, the Panama canal authority could have easily covered the cost of a well-thought out and executed project. With the stakes as high as they are, I'm surprised that this option was not pursued.

There seems to be a lot of confusion over the way the article read vs. the stars conferred, but it actually matches my experience. In fact, despite agreeing qualitatively, I think one star is kind. It suggests that although the restaurant's food actually isn't very good, he hates to speak ill of it because it was so charming and well intentioned.

To wit, when he says that on some nights the schnitzel "doesn't crunch as emphatically as you want it to", he's basically romanticizing the fact that the wiener schnitzel is often clumsily and poorly executed. In no way should that be praiseworthy, but he is charmed enough to rationalize it as part of trying to seem like a longer-tenured restaurant. In my experience, the schnitzel was just mediocre and sloppy. A huge gaffe at a restaurant that is playing at being traditional Austrian. And even worse in light of all the infinitely better schnitzels available in town, such as the ones at Seasonal and Edi & The Wolf. Wells was kind not to trash it.

Similarly, he wrote about the about the spaetzle in the goulash, but doesn't actually praise the goulash itself. It's as if he's trying to avoid mentioning that the meat was embarrassingly poorly butchered. Every bite contained connective tissue, unpleasantly jiggly bits, or stuff you'd want trimmed off in a version costing $30. Wells wanted to like the place more than he did, but their actual food is sub par, and if you're going to try to produce nostalgia, that requires better execution.

Although I love reading Pete Wells's reviews, I have been consistently baffled over the last couple of years by the number of stars that end up being given to each restaurant in question. There seems to be absolutely no relationship between what he tells us the restaurant, its service, its ambiance, and its food are like and the number of final judgmental stars.

Given everything he wrote about this place, I would have certainly thought that it would be rated as two stars, possibly even three. But one?

I see that I am not alone in being baffled by this....

No one expected the Canal to miraculously expand overnight. It was designed and built over a period of years. Larger ships were built in anticipation.

Pardon my ignorance but who would build ships that are too large for existing locks?  Did entities just decide to make bigger ships and expect that the Panama Canal would miraculously expand overnight?

I'm afraid the expansion of The Canal is a continued effort to modernize because of the ever expanding trade. Trade is great, but the size of ships and the colossal growth of this industry reflects the inequality of our trade. With virtually everything made NOT IN AMERICA, all these imports are dependent on travel through the canal. It's all part of the oligarchy and the squeeze on working people. The shipping industry is not what it used to be. It is a virtual pipeline to everything we now own and don't make her, unfortunately.

The commenters extolling the original engineering saying it should have simply been duplicated? Please compare things from today with a century ago. Planes? Phones? Automobiles? Elevators? Skyscrapers? Ships? Bridges? X rays versus CT and MRI scans. Night and day.
Then compare the following: computers, televisions, satellites, rockets, research vessels exploring the solar system and beyond. Nanotechnology and genetic engineering. Organ transplants, open heart surgery, and not last nor least, the internet. Oh, none of them existed in 1914.
It's called progress folks. Corruption and incompetence can muddy things up, but to deny that we've made exponential progress in every realm of technology in the last century is simply laughable.

Seems that a fleet of specialized propellor driven 'waterborne mules' (water mules) equipped with adjustable rollers/wheels to bear on the lock walls and with positioning gear to keep the very large ships centered in the lock would easily take care safely getting the very large ships thru the locks. Coventional tugs could be used on the conventionally sized ships.
Now getting the 'water mules' re-positioned for the next cargo ship after clearing the lock would slow things down, probably more than what is now required to re-position the conventional tugs now used.
The faulty construction of the locks is going to be a real tough one to fix. When they eventionally must redo the work, they can install conventional land-mules as was orginally done.

Why was the original canal an engineering masterpiece while this one seems deeply flawed?  To me, this is a story of the corrupting influence of corporations.    The original canal was built by the U.S. government, supervised by the Army Corps of Engineers.  They got the job done, and well.  Now that major public works projects are contracted out to corporations looking to make profit at the public's expense, these sorts of scandals happen all the time.  Bechtel, portrayed as the "responsible" bidder here, was at fault for many of Boston's "Big Dig" tunnel problems - a woman was killed when part of the tunnel collapsed on her car in 2006 and Bechtel was fined hundreds of millions of dollars for their negligence.   Or look at the cracking on the $6 billion+ San Francisco / Oakland bridge replacement.  Corporations put their profits first and this is the result.

The one thing I have learned in this life is that every single time I try to do something on the cheap I get burned badly. If you want something done right you almost always have to pay more than you originally thought. I guess the leaders of this project live in a different world.
